summary: Poor or short sleep is associated with lower next-day mood and stress resilience.
observed_patterns: Sleep quality low → next-day mood lower
implication_logic: If sleep was poor, mood and resilience the next day may be lower. Improving sleep timing often helps before targeting mood alone.
intervention_leverage: Stabilize sleep timing and reduce evening stress before adding mood-specific interventions.

summary: High stress can reduce mood stability. Recovery (sleep, timing, hydration) supports resilience.
implication_logic: If stress is high, mood may dip; addressing upstream (sleep, rhythm) often supports mood more than mood-focused advice alone.
intervention_leverage: Address sleep and stress first; consistency in timing and recovery supports mood.
